title: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine declines to participate in gubernatorial debate

sentence: Both Democrats running for governor, former Cincinnati Mayor John Cranley and former Dayton Mayor Nan Whaley, have agreed to debate.

title: Ohio governor's race: Mike DeWine won't debate Republicans hoping to unseat him

sentence: While Whaley called DeWine’s signing of the legislation “shameless and disgraceful,” her Democratic primary opponent John Cranley took it one step further by claiming that the governor’s approval “stains Mike DeWine’s soul.” Heck, even some of DeWine’s primary opponents are going after him on the issue, though not because they’re opposed to Constitutional Carry.
author: Cam Edwards
title: Democratic knives come out for DeWine after Constitutional Carry signed

sentence: “What’s happened with the GOP candidates and the governor’s race is disappointing,” said ODC Board President Dan Moulthrop in a written statement, “but when the incumbent chooses not to debate, it’s not surprising that others in the race have less incentive to do so as well.” The Democratic candidates for governor – John Cranley and Nan Whaley -- have confirmed their intent to participate in the debate to be held March 29 at 7 p.m. at Central State University’s Robeson Cultural & Performing Arts Center.
title: Ohio Republican gubernatorial debate canceled after DeWine, Renacci bow out

sentence: The Ohio Debate Commission will hold a debate for Democratic candidates for governor, former Dayton Mayor Nan Whaley and former Cincinnati Mayor John Cranley.

sentence: The two Democratic candidates for governor, former Dayton Mayor Nan Whaley and ex-Cincinnati Mayor John Cranley, are still scheduled to debate March 29.

sentence: Meeting in their first primary debate, ex-Cincinnati Mayor John Cranley and former Dayton Mayor Nan Whaley blamed DeWine for enabling the $60 million statehouse bribery scheme, failing to pass meaningful gun reforms and flip-flopping on mask mandates.
